text: Walter Mitty (30s) sits at his small kitchen table, balan his check book. We see his last several expense entries:
Mom's new apt. deposit
O's braces (2nd installment)
Piano delivery to Mom's new apt.
In-piano humidity control system

During the morning rush hour, a crowd of businessmen wait the corner to cross the street. Walter is among them, dre in a short-sleeve business shirt and tie and with a brief on hand. Nothing happens. Then Walter's head explodes.
Up toward the clouds, propelled skyward, were the content (ideas and images) of Walter's head; they've begun to flo toward the ground.
Some office work is going on. Then past the window (outsi comes floating down, in slow motion, Juan Valdez the Colombian Coffee guy (his donkey's floating down way in t distance).

This happens outside other high-rise and professional building windows - a floating Bishop Desmond Tutu, the silver Monopoly piece Top Hat, Statler and Waldorf (the t elderly curmudgeons from The Muppet Show) and additional detritus from Walter's mind such as Manute Bol, The Beast Boys, etc. CREDITS PLAY.
Walter sits at a Midtown Starbucks. He's got his laptop o and he's in the middle of a phone call.
You know, you didn't really provide much detail about your occupation. Most people put theirs on their eHarmony page. You don't care to?
Is that like a must? Can't I just say like "I'm employed" or something?
(like okay but that's not a great idea) Sure.
My work's not really that interesting. To women. Um. Or men.
What do you do?
I'm a Practical Asset Manager. For a corporation.
(sounds like he agrees it's not interesting) ....okay. What do you do when you're not working?
Mostly I guess I commute to work? It's like an hour and--
Okay. No worries. I'll submit this information, then check back in the afternoon for your possible eHarmony matchups. That's exciting, huh?
It is, Todd. Yeah. Hey, when can I leave a "wink" for someone? To see if they "wink" back, or..?

Walter's looking at his laptop. On screen is the eHarmony dating page for CHERYL M. (34), pretty but she looks like sort of pretty girl who takes the bus; text beside her ph reads "Leave a wink for Cheryl M. to indicate your interest..."
I'll have your eHarmony profile all uploaded in a minute.
Cool.
So like in two minutes. But hey, you're a little light, if you don't mind me saying this, in your "Been There, Done that" column.
Part of the eHarmony client profile has a section Been Th Done That - where people list their accomplishments, trav etc.
I forgot what I put there?
...Nothing.
Oh, okay.
We should beef that up. If you can think of anything to add that would make it, you know, not blank.... give me a ring, I'll add it.
I sure will.
(like he's a little
...Are you okay, man?
(doesn't know the guy, surprised he asked) ...Me?
Yeah.
Yeah. Why?
You sound, I don't know, a little stressed?
(thinks its odd this guy's taking a personal
No, I just had some stuff on my mind. The past couple months.
....What kind of stuff?
(still thinking this personal interest is a
Just, you know... life stuff.
Yeah, I get that.
Some awkward moments pass as Walter's unsure about follow through on heavy conversation with a stranger.
...okay thanks for asking, I guess, um, Todd was your name?
Todd Mahar. I'll be your eHarmony counselor, while you're with us here at eHarmony.
Okay. Cool.
Yeah. Hey, let's hope you'll have a special lady on your mind later today.
Sounds good, Todd.
Later, Walter.
Later... Todd.

They finish their call. Walter looks at the computer pict of Cheryl M., then out the window at actual Cheryl M. (CH MELHOFF, 34) crossing the street just outside the window the Time-Life building lobby. Then as Walter stands to go outside the Starbucks window, a grand piano (exploded fro Walter's head) falls from the sky onto the middle of the street.

Walter's out on 6th among a crowd waiting for a light to cross. Then a black and white New Orleans Jazz Funeral procession passes in front of him - black and white in th sense everyone in it and all their instruments and lively waving umbrellas are in black and white. Walter and the business people around them are in color. CREDITS END. Th title appears: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty.
Walter crosses the expansive lobby and passes a colleague on his way to the building elevators.
Walter.
What's up, Roy?
Hey. We just got acquired. Our company. This morning.
Our whole company did?
Walter wasn't expecting this; it's thrown him some.
Walter's in an elevator with two other guys in suits. He addresses the first one (GARY MANNHEIM)
Gary? You're Vice President of Acquisitions. Right?
Yeah.
... we just got acquired. Did you know that? Roy said.
The company that I'm supposed to be acquiring companies for? It just got acquired?
Yeah, Roy said.
Okay, that's not promising for me probably.
Yeah, they probably have their own acquiring guy.
He's probably the guy who acquired us.
Yeah. That was me. Ted Hendricks. Hey.
This is the second man in a suit (TED HENDRICKS) who's be with them all the while. They all shake hands.
Ted Hendricks. Vice President of Acquisitions.
Gary Mannheim. Um. Vice President of Acquisitions. Too. So what are you going to be doing at the company, Ted?
Managing the acquisition. Identifying overlap. Reducing staff where we find redundancy. What's your focus been here, Gary?
...I've been managing acquisitions. Identifying overlap. Then reducing staff where I find redundancy.
Further awkward moments pass.
Wow, okay. That's not...
Yeah, that's not good.
No.
What do you do?
I'm a Practical Asset Manager.
Do you play an important role here?
I do. Yeah. Totally. I work in a one-on-one basis (on a one-on-one basis I mean) with all our photographers.
Ted just looks at him for a moment.
I'm sorry. I was really getting into this song. What were you saying?
Walter listens to the elevator muzak Ted just referred to It's like Maneater in muzak; no one could get into it.
I was just saying I manage our film negatives from the moment they arri-
(starting to leave) Let's talk later. We have a specific time set aside to conference with employees of the former company.
What time is that?
I'm not sure. But it's not at this time.
Okay.
I have to see the board and start evaluations now.
Okay. Thank you. (flustered, feeling that was a dumb thing to say) I mean "not thank you." I mean like "looking forward to it" I should have said.
Ted just looks over. The door's closing.
(through the closing
Looking forward to it.
The doors are almost closed.
I'll come by sometime this week.
Awesome.
Are you going to come by my...um?
The doors close. Ted's not coming by Gary's office.

Walter walks up a long hallway toward his department floo on the walls are hugely blown up Life Magazine photograph Twelve foot high Muhammad Ali, Morgan Freeman (Oscar pose Moon Landings. - Walter looks small compared. The last ph he passes is familiar - a black and white of a New Orlean Jazz Funeral.
The division Walter works in has fifty employees seated around an open floor plan - fifty cubicles in view. Walte arrived at his to find on his desk a wrapped gift with a
Heard rumbling's Life's over. Wanted to give you somethin cool if this is the last photo batch. Hope when you open and look inside you'll think it's pretty special.
Walter's unwrapped the gift.
It's a leather wallet. Its front is embossed with the inscription from S.O. to Walter Mitty - thanks for the gr work.
Walter looks back at the letter; it finishes - by the way neg 12 is my best ever. Landmark. The Absolute Quintessen of Life. .... the rest of the batch kind of sucks. Sean

Walter has been working through a Life photo order negati box - it's marked Sean O'Connell. There's a co-worker (HERNANDO) cleaning up in the distance. Walter has been examining a negative roll with his loupes (magnifiers wor eye glasses). THEN HE NOTICES SOMETHING THAT STOPS HIM. T negative roll, where the 12th negative should be, has bee cut; 12 is missing.
Hey, Hernando-
Yeah?
This 12th neg? From this last Life roll?
Yeah.
It's not here.
What's it of?
It's of something that's the Absolute Quintessence of Life. Or something.
What's "quintessence?"
It means like the best ever.
A moment goes by.
And you can't find it?
Um no.
Wow. That's not going to go over well with the new asshole.

The storage room is separated from the greater division f by a wide glass window wall. At that moment, Walter has noticed new supervisor Ted Hendricks on the other side of glass. He's holding a conversation with a LIFE EDITOR the Walter can hear it (muffled).
How's the issue shaping up?
We got an email from Sean O'Connell.
The photographer?
Yes. He said he got the cover shot. His best. The Quintessence of Life.
What does Quintessence mean?
Like the best ever.
Okay. Awesome.
Ted starts to walk away.
(repeating to himself for
Quintessence.
This has Walter concerned.

The cafeteria is a large white room, with massive black a white Life photographs serving essentially as wallpaper. Particularly, they are images of physical and human immen (photographs of the summitting of K2 and the beachheads o Normandy) and make the office workers here (Life magazine low-level corporate workers among whom Walter is one) see tiny in terms of their personal accomplishments but also physically. Walter and a co-worker TIM NAUGHTON sit in fr of the Massive K2 mountain summit photograph.
Tim, did you find out anything about Negative Box 2-6? Where it was sent from?
(like he's a real big
That's the Sean O'Connell commission?
Yeah, the guy who took this--
Walter gestures to the K2. It's taken from above a guy wh just summitted.
There's nothing in shipping. The box just showed up it seems like. There's no receipt.
...I'm getting nervous with these new guys around. Lost negative. But I'm not going to freak out. I think my work here the last nine years speaks for itself. I've made my mark.
Then new superior Ted Hendricks walks past, accompanied b Life's EXECUTIVE ADMINISTRATORS.
Who am I evaluating next?
(holding an employee file labeled W. Mitty) W. Mitty.
Who's that?
He's the black guy from Accounts.
...He's not black.
Are you sure?
Yeah. He's just a white guy. With a mustache.
He doesn't have a mustache.
Of course he doesn't have a mustache. He's a woman.
They've walked past Walter and out of the cafeteria - but Walter's heard every word - not promising.

Walter sits at the cement bench on 6th just out front of Time-Life building. He's looking at a photograph he's tak from his briefcase. It's a bad print - the kind someone t before their camera's set - over exposed, out of focus - impossible to discern the subject.
What is this?
Cheryl Mellhoff sits down beside Walter.
What is this?
He hands her the foggy print - it's clear they have an established working friendship.
I think it's either a man with one sideburn. Or a candelabra. Or a Happy Days lunch box.
(can't make it out clearly
It's... is it two badminton racquets? What's it supposed to be?
It's the Quintessence of Life. So I don't think it's two badminton racquets. Sean O'Connell took this just before he took another one we lost.
(like that's significant) You lost a Sean O'Connell?
(looking at the out of
...I'm trying to figure out what this picture is. I think he focused, set his lens then took the missing picture. It's just a better picture of this. What is this?
Maybe Sean has it.
The negative? Yeah, I tried to reach him. He's always in Bahrain. Or a shanty town or somewhere - I got one email off.
Walter shows Cheryl an email exchange from Sean O'Connell
It reads - in need of info for neg 12 of neg roll three, 2-6.
Sean's reply - Best picture I've taken. The total F'ing Quintessence of Life. I hope you're as happy with it as I
Walter's reply = Cool, but can't find it.
Sean's reply - Out of Office. This is an auto reply. Sean O'Connell will be out of the office through the month of November.
No cell phone. He's out on a freelance. I'd really like to find him.
Walter has taken further photographs from his briefcase
These are pictures from the last roll he sent in. I'm trying to draw a bead on his location by analyzing these.
Have you figured anything out?
Not yet. Because my trail is... water.
Walter starts showing Cheryl the photographs. The first o which is water - just a picture of water, could be an oce lake, or pool (puddle).
A Starbucks, which I don't know which one. (flipping to the next one) And a man (or woman's) thumb.
This is a picture of a thumb.
I've been trying to figure out the gender (of the thumb), as I sat here. How many people in the world?
Six billion.
Everyone's got two, too.
Two, too, what?
Thumbs.
Yeah. But I think there are more Starbucks, so I don't know if that's what you'd call a hot trail--
Look what Sean gave me.
Walter has taken the gift wallet out - S.O. to Walter Mit thanks for the great work.
Because we covered, you know, so many hotspots together the last 9 years... (a little more quietly) ...boldly
(having some fun with
You guys covered the hotspots together boldly?
As a team. Yeah. By Sean actually going to the hotspots, and by me staying here waiting for the pictures of hotspots to come back so I can boldly transfer them to magazine format.
Cheryl's laughed.
...What did you do this weekend?
We're moving my mom here. I went and packed her house up. What about you?

My son and I went on a bike ride in Lake Valhalla. Jersey. We brought lunch. Had lunch in an actual field, of grass. We went swimming. My friend Marny lives on the lake. (getting to what's on everyone's minds around

...This is going to be the last issue. Life's going to be strictly online after this merger. No new photographs. We're just going to be an internet photo storehouse. That's what I'm hearing. They're going to let most of us go.
Walter sits there for awhile. That's tough news. He's got lot on his mind. Then he gets a text: From Odessa, it rea
- piano a-holes want 300 more dollars to take the piano b come down. I have to go. Like right now.

Walter's running through the huge Time-Life lobby for the 50th St. glass exit doors, but outside the lobby it's not York right now. It's Sana'a, Yemen. And running parallel Walter, along the window glass wall beside him, is rugged photographer SEAN O'CONNELL, loaded with camera gear. Wal runs out the building entrance and is now running side by side with Sean in Sana'a, Yemen in the midst of an anti- American rally, making a desperate dash together out of t under a volley of middle-eastern shoes.
What's with all these shoes?
Angry Middle-easterners are throwing their shoes at Walte and Sean as they sprint by.
It's a sign of disdain here.
That's a lot of shoes, man.
They've been targeting western journalists all summer. It's been a real hot August.
Thanks for doing all the field work here and risking your ass and getting hit by shoes and stuff.
Let's just get this camera bag out of here. We can shoot the shit later, O'Connell. Over whiskeys.
There are in Sana'a, Yemen, but they're chasing an actual metro south. Walter has finally reached its doors, though he's continuously struck by shoes.

Walter's slightly out of breath. He's caught the bus. It' just New York again. Walter walks up the crowded bus aisl and finds a seat. Some time passes. Walter looks out the window, his daydream has faded.

A little later, Walter's got his lap top out, trying to l a "wink" for Cheryl M. (Cheryl Mellhoff) on eHarmony . It doesn't work: unable to perform request. Walter looks at it's not the smooth next step he was expecting. He tries again. Same result.
Walter's in the midst of a phone call.
I tried to leave a "wink." For someone. But it didn't work.
Well, they're not required to respond to you favorably. We can't
No, it says "unable to perform request," Todd. So I don't think my wink really went through. Do I have like a broken page or something?
Broken page? I've never heard of that.
Well, okay, something's not working. On my page.
Yeah, let me look here
Okay, we received your application breaking your personality into 29 different dimensions, and, okay, I see the problem. You don't have any.
Any what?
Dimensions.
Further time passes.
...I don't have any dimensions?

Not that we can determine. Through our models. You're just lacking distinguishing features as our system sees it. Based on our really extensive evaluation, you seem, to us, a little too indistinguishable from everybody else.
A pretty long time passes as Walter wrestles with this consideration.
You're not standing out. In a way that would allow anyone to actually notice you. So hey, let's enhance your profile. Let me ask you, did you always want to be a practical asset manager?
I don't want to be one now. I just am one.
Why do you do it?
It's an occupation. When I became an adult I thought that would be possibly a good thing to have. Because I keep getting bills from places.
What are some of your accomplishments?
...I studied music.
How long?
April.
April? One April?
Yeah. But I was working at Orange Julius to save money for college. That April. And my hands were always sore from working the Frother.
Can you play any pieces?
Sure.
Which?
A piece of Cheers. The first piece. Part.
I don't know if we should list that.
Walter gets a text from Odessa that says I'm leaving.
Hey, Todd. I have to go. I have a piano situation I have to take care of.
Okay, man.
Um hey, can I have my four hundred dollars back?
Walter walks up to Battery Park to find (really) a grand piano sitting in the park. He stops and stares at it awhi

Walter sits at the abandoned piano (in pristine shape). Regular NY foot traffic passes around him. He absentminde starts playing the first bars of Cheers. Then he just kee doing it because he's thinking of other things.
Stop playing Cheers, Dick.
Then Walter sees Cheryl Mellhoff and her son RICH (9), he his way from across Bridge Street. They've got two skateboards. Walter smiles when he sees them and waves.

Cheryl, Walter and Rich push the grand piano toward quiet Bridge Street. It's on its wheels and a couple skateboard It's rolling down the street pretty well. They're about t push it out onto the street.
Rich, are you ready to push a piano down a street and get honked at by everybody in New York?
(like it's going to be
Yeah.
They do. The honking begins right away, but they keep rol the grand piano down Bridge Street. It looks like it migh fun.
I can't believe they left it in the park. How old is this?
Her dad bought it for her when she was six. It's seventy-years-old.
Your sister just took off?
My sister's not the responsible one in the family.
No kidding, man.

She told them no steps. I paid them for a first floor move. But she screwed up and got my mom a apartment on the 15th floor. The movers weren't equipped to get it up there. She didn't have the money for them to take it back. She had to get her braces adjusted, so she just took off.
Braces. How old is she?
It's pretty late now. Walter has placed a tarp over the piano. They rolled it into a city parking space.
You're sure this is your sister's parking space?
Yeah. Hey, Rich. You're pretty good on that.
Rich is skateboarding around a little.
I used to skateboard a little.
(something about the idea makes her smile) When?
Maine. When I was a kid. (trying to unburden her of the other skateboard) Hey. I'll bring it in tomorrow. I don't want you to have to carry it all the way home. I got it.
Thanks.
You helped me move a piano. I can carry this. See you Rich. Thanks for putting your back into it.
What does that mean?
Just, you know... helping out, man.
See you tomorrow.
Yeah.
Walter's got the piano all tarped. Cheryl and Rich take o
Are you sure I can't walk you home?
I'm going to drop Rich at his Dad's. Thanks, Walter.
Walter hangs out a moment. He's watching them go. Then he starts walking off with Rich's skateboard.

Walter's alone again. He's back near the park in the city waiting to cross State. He puts the skateboard down and starts kind of messing around with it a little, moving ar on it a little bit. Then he takes off on it pretty well, he grinds the low garden curb - nicely done.
Walter's got the water photo under a light lamp. He's scrutinizing it, hoping to gain some information.
(quietly, to himself) Is this the Arctic Ocean..? A glass of Sprite.

Then he finds something. There's been a light leak at the edge of the frame. Here, with the picture blown-up and li poured on, Walter can make out something reflected in the water. It's the stern of a fishing trawler. Its vessel na and registry number are visible. She's the Erkigsnek SO70 Her port home is almost visible painted beneath, but only first two letters are legible due to the light leak - Nu.
Walter and his colleague Tim Naughton have met up in thei breakroom, having some coffee.  On the wall beyond them i massive photo of Evel Knievel on fire.
Hey were you able to use the Circulation computer to find that ship? That boat?
Yeah, it's registered in Nuuk.
Nuuk?
That's a town. I think the town in Greenland. It's a coastal fishing vessel.
....Greenland.
Walter considers that. It connects to nothing for him. He turns to other matters.
Tim, what would you say is a good accomplishment of yours, like something that you'd put on an online dating page?
I don't know.
Tim considers this.
I broke Adam Lopez's record for hitting the highest singing note for a male, I guess.
Seriously?
Yeah.
After a moment, Gary hits the highest singing note ever recorded for a male.
Wow...
But I don't know if I'd put that on eHarmony.
I just don't think that's really going to do a lot for the ladies.
Yeah. How did you know you can do that?
My voice goes way up there when I'm emotional, or whatever, can't really control it.
I was thinking about putting that I've never really been late coming back from lunch.
...I don't know. Kind of weak. That's not exactly winning the Tour de France.
...Yeah

location: CHOPPED SALAD, CHAIN SALAD FAST FOOD RESTAURANT

text: Walter is visible at a table for one. He's finishing up lunch. He checks his watch. Then he stands to leave to ge back to work on time.

Walter's running to the subway station a half-block ahead Then he passes a man who's just standing there silently extending (to Walter) a cup of water. Walter takes it wit breaking stride, drinks it and drops the cup on the sidew it was unusual. Then Walter hustles down the subway steps and checks his watch to ensure he's running on time.
Walter has taken his subway seat. Then a shirtless, beami Frenchman leans into view (in the seat behind Walter's) a offers Walter pats (congratulatory) on the back.

Walter's made it to the corner of 6th and 49th. He looks ahead at the Time-Life building (his destination). Then h checks his watch and finds he'll be on time. He's relieve Then a Frenchman comes up and sprays Walter in the face w Champagne. Then multiple Frenchmen mob Walter, fighting f turns at congratulating him through frantic head rubs.
Walter is carried on the group of Frenchmen's shoulders a they run him up 6th avenue, chanting.
(European sports chant) Wal-ter Mi-tty.
The French mob jogs through the lobby with Walter atop th shoulders.
(European sports chant) Wal-ter Mi-tty.
Among more serious-looking businessmen and woman, the rau tour-de-France style congratulations party continues. Walter's just being mobbed by ecstatic Frenchmen.

No one's around. We hear the quiet "ding" of the elevator arriving. Then Walter gets out. There are no crowds anywh just Walter in his short-sleeve dress shirt, tie and briefcase. He reaches his division floor offices door and enters his pass-key. Then his mom walks up - EDNA MITTY,
Hi, honey.
(noticing her, surprised) Hey, Mom.
Hi, Walter. Is it all right I'm dropping by?
Sure, (meaning the open office
we'll just go through here to my office.
As Walter and Edna enter the division floor, colleague Ti Naughton walks past.
They just called a conference.
(following Tim, with his mom at his side, to her) Hey, your new place is almost ready. We just had a little hiccup due to Odessa just not getting the right one.
Well, she's the artist...
Why did she get the cool name? She got to turn out cool.
I named her after a wonderful visit your Dad and I had to Odessa, our family's homeland, one summer, in southern Ukraine. There's a beautiful river there also named Odessa.
Why did you name me Walter?
I named you after Walter Matthau
(noticing that a conference is starting) Okay. This is starting I think. We should probably just stop here to--

They've walked out onto the division floor where a group forty or so employees has been gathered together to allow Hendricks a speech (which he's forcing a colleague to mak They stand a short distance away, in the middle of lettin
This will only take a moment. I just wanted to inform you all, reluctantly, that this month's issue will be the last.
The employees have been expecting this. Nonetheless, the saddens and concerns them.
You are all valued employees. But as we undergo this transition we wanted to be candid with you that some of you will be--
(correcting him, a little more quietly, just to
Most.
(to Ted, quietly) What's that?
Most of them.

We wanted to be clear that most of you will be determined non-vital to the new partnership. The remaining few employees will carry over into the new organization. We'll be deciding which category your positions fall into over the course of the next week.
Tim Naughton, among the gathered (soon to be former) employees, has begun a quiet, high-pitched, weeping. Walt has had to field this news while his mother stands beside him.
Now for some good news. We're very
At this point, Ted Hendricks nudges the guy to move over Ted can assume the speaking part for the good news portio

Okay. So, we're very excited to play a part in publishing what will be the very last issue of Life Magazine, which has been an American Institution for 75 years and whose renowned covers have touched us all really touching ways. And for the final issue, our cover is going to be something which is... (he forgot the word, looks at the editor for help) What was that word?
Quintessence.

Our cover will probably be the most famous ever because it really has the awesome quintessence of Life. And we're all going to be a part of this historic happening. Even those of you who will, right after the happening, be asked to leave. Thank you.

Ted begins to clap (for some reason). So the gathered employees also begin some watered-down clapping. Walter i among them, standing beside his mom, who is clapping too. Then they all stop the fake good cheer and head back to w

head_text.subj: INT. STORAGE ROOM, PRACTICAL ASSETS, LIFE

text: Later, Walter's mom is with him in his work area, back in storage area of practical assets.
(to colleague Hernando, little rattled about the quintessence cover news) Check for negative 12 in the wash bins.
So the moving bill came, for my move down here. I wanted to bring it by. Thank you so much Walter.
Mom, come on. It's nothing.
Walter takes his mom's bill. He's paying it. He seems a little worried about money. Hernando comes back into the area.
(about the negative) It's not in there, Walter.
It's bad news. Walter is going to have to tell his superi the negative is lost.

Walter has approached (reluctantly) Ted Hendrick's office confess the negative's gone. But he finds Ted on the phon and waits politely in the open doorway for Ted to finish call. (Ted has his back to Walter).
Yes, sir. It's gone very smoothly. The last issue's underway.

The cover? Yeah. It's amazing. It's so quintessence. It encapsulates majesty. Totally. It has some splendor, in it, too, probably. Also, I'm pretty sure it's illustrious and just really awesome. It took my breath away. And I haven't even seen it yet.
We're getting it processed from practical assets now.
Yes, sir. We're going to retain eleven employees. I'm going to be evaluating them over the next week.
His situation worsened, Walter turns and leaves.

head_text.subj: INT. STORAGE ROOM, PRACTICAL ASSETS, LIFE

text: Walter has returned to the storage room. He's looking at laptop at a map of Earth. Specifically, at Greenland. Hernando's working in the distance.
You know, the thing about Greenland... it's really not that far, man.
What's that?
Greenland.
What's Greenland?
It's a country/island. Sean might be there. It's not as close as Canada but it's really not as far as it sounds. When you hear it. Look.
Hernando looks at the map. It is (actually) really not th far from Canada.
Yeah, it's not that far.
Then Walter leaves the room.
Everyone's at work, in the cubicle spaces. Walter comes walking through the area, with his briefcase, on his way
Walter's out walking among the crowds. But he's moving wi some purpose, somewhere specific. All he's got is his briefcase.
Walter Mitty is Out of the Office. This is an automatic r

The plane is mostly empty. But Walter's on it. And just o other guy. But he's sitting in the seat beside Walter. Th Captain's speaking Danish. Walter's looking at his iphone email from the photographer Sean O'Connell - Best picture I've taken. The total "F"ing quintessence of Life. Walter looks at this message like there's hope there, like findi this thing might save his job. The plane takes off now, soars.
The plane's midair. Walter's looking at the photo print t image of which (out of focus) he can't make out, trying t unlock some idea of what it is.
The capital, coastal town of Nuuk looks like it's made ou Victorian toys. Walter's plane drops into view and descen over these handsome little buildings.

Walter has somehow gotten involved in a Danish folkdance which involves (exclusively) linking arms with elderly Greenlanders in colorful vests (the only colorful part of event) and shuffling slowly from side to side while makin large moving (slow) outer circle. Also they chant in Dani Walter performs this holding his briefcase.
Outside the pub, Walter has been showing Greenlander teen his overexposed photograph.
This looks like a chair. Here.
It doesn't really look like a chair.
Have you seen this chair?
That's not a chair.
I think it's a chair. Or a pipe. A man's pipe.
No one says anything.
Have you seen this pipe?
That's not a pipe either.
(showing them another
Have you seen this Starbucks?
I don't know. Possibly.
Have you seen this man (or woman's) thumb?
It's a fresh morning. Walter's sitting in a coffee shop, looking out on the capital town street. Then he sees a ca pull up for him.
Walter sits in back. The older female cabby cruises the c past some open, pretty fields.
Greenland is the least densely populated country in the world. There's only 56,000 people. Lots to do. Most of us work a few different jobs, to cover everything. For example I drive this cab.
A moment passes.
I'm also the Queen.
Walter has been surprised.
...You're the Queen of Greenland?
Yeah. Oh, there goes my meter.
Her meter's gone out.
You want to just a call it 93 kroner? Flat rate.
That's cool... your Majesty.
An awkward moment passes.
Should I call you that?
Sure.
Is there anything around here that a renowned photographer might be photographing?
No.
Are you sure?
Yes.
I think he was here.
Well, possibly if he was mistaken, he might have thought the Musk Ox migration was worth photographing.
Can we see that?
Walter and the Queen continue their peaceful drive throug the outskirts of Nuuk, Greenland.
So are you Queen for life?
Yeah.
That's a good gig. They're making some changes at work. My work. They're letting most of the divisions go.
How long have you been there?
Nine years.
That's tough.
How'd you get to be Queen?
My dad was King.
...My dad sold ice cream.
Here we are.
Walter looks out the window. In a field they've parked beside, there are a few indigenous Oxen (they look like h Jim Henson muppets) walking slowly.
That's the Musk Ox migration?
Yeah.
There's just three of them.
Yeah.
Where are they migrating?
To the other side of the island.
(like it's not that big a
Yeah, I don't think Sean would cover this, so much. Can you just take me to the boat wharf place?
At the end of a dock, with western Nuuk in the distance behind them and the Atlantic all around, Walter holds a conversation with an older BOAT CAPTAIN. The cab waits in distance.
You're the captain of the Erkigsnek? I don't know how to pronounce that.
That wasn't right. But yeah, I know what you're trying to say. Yeah. I am.
Walter shows him the water photo.
You're boat was photographed. In the past four days. Do you know where?
He looks at the photo for a while.
We've been out in the Atlantic the last four days. I have no idea when this was taken.
Can you guess from where?
Where it was taken from?
Yeah.
...another ship? Which I can't say. We passed a lot of them. You should check the mail logs at the post office.
Walter's at the desk of the small post office.
Are you a detective?
Yep.
Some moments pass.
Did I just say "yep?" I'm sorry. I meant "nope." I'm an office worker. We're trying to secure a photograph he might have, that's valuable to my company.
Well, these are the airmail records from this last week. (checking a large
They helicopter mail in. As the shipping freighters go by. We had fifty three pick ups. That's fifty three freighters. He could have been on any one of them.
So he just went by us?
If he was on a freighter, he went right by us.
So there's no one here who might have had contact with him, who might know where he's going.
I'm afraid I can't help you.
A moment passes.
Unless you want to mail something.
(just standing there) No, I don't have any... mailing needs.

Learning Sean has slipped into the unknown again, Walter' despondent; he sits at the bar, drinking a beer out of wh looks a glass, woman's boot (it's huge). The same folk da dance is going on behind him. But he's not engaged. He's looking at the blown up photograph of "the thumb." He's j staring at it like it's never going to grant him anything thumb - then after a moment a real thumb that looks just that thumb appears beside it, attached to the hand of a g who's just walked up to the bar and put his hand on it (o the bar beside the photo). The two thumbs rest beside one another. They're the same thumb. After a brief moment, Wa notices the resemblance. Then he turns and looks at the g The guy looks back.
Can I ask you a question?
Sure.
Where was your thumb like four days ago?
Walter has come outside the pub to talk to this guy. Ther a helicopter parked in the field beyond the pub. The thum guy is its PILOT.
I can't believe I found one thumb.
Well, it's the least densely populated country on earth. It's a good place to find a thumb. He's on the Dolores. I helicopter dropped and picked up mail from her Tuesday. He's a strange guy.
Sean?
Yeah. He took a picture of my thumb.
Yeah, why?
He saw I worked my controls with it. He's shooting photos of people working. That's why he's on that ship. I'm taking some radio parts out there in fifteen minutes. Their radio's fucked.
Man, I really need to contact him. We're in a transition period and--
You could contact him by coming with me. Then contacting him. In person. On the boat.
...Can't we just call them? I could ask him on like the boat phone.
The Ship to shore.
Can I just ask him on the "ship to shore?" Instead of going on that old-looking helicopter?
Well, their radio's fucked. That's why I'm flying out.
You're leaving now?
After I finish my beer.
That makes Walter pause.
The weather doesn't seem great. Feels like there a storm "moving in." "Brewing."
Yeah.
But you're just going to finish
and then fly?
Yeah.
Okay. I'm not going to go with you.
The pilot sits at the bar finishing his boot beer. Walter in the background, looking in through the window, watchin the pilot drink.
A little while later, the pilot's in the pilot's chair of helicopter. The blades are spinning.

He's about to lift off out of Nuuk. Walter's in the dista standing thirty yards away near the pub, looking over. He not going. Then the helicopter starts to lift at the same moment Walter has a change of heart and starts to run tow it to come along.

The helicopter begins to ascend (the environment around t pub is pretty, different than what we've seen). We also haven't seen Walter sprinting before, which he is now (briefcase), arriving, then leaping three feet up into th passenger seat of the helicopter.
Walter's high above Greenland, flying over a fjord. It's breathtaking. He yells to be heard from the passenger sea the pilot.
Is that a fjord?
Yeah.
I've seen pictures of fjords. But I've never actually seen a fjord. I don't think I've ever even said the word fjord out loud--
Stop saying fjord. It's annoying.
Okay.
This is a look from way up at an international shipping vessel mid-sea. The weather around it's getting rocky. On deck, they're prepping a life raft.
Walter's getting rocked a little in the helicopter passen seat. The weather's getting rough. They're in some low ly storm clouds.
(yelling over the blades) We're not going to be able to land on the freighter. I've got to drop the radio parts and you in a life raft.
It's a short drop, but your decision. You can just fly back with me.

(yelling over the blades) I'd really like to get my hands on this property. They're making some changes at the office. It's going to reflect poorly on my work. I might get let go. And I have a mounting piano situation that's-- (rocked big time) Whoa...
The pilot carries on to the freighter. Walter seems to be calling on his reserves to see this through.
It's noisy. The weather's rough. There is lots of lifting dropping. Walter's steadying himself in the cargo hold, preparing to jump..
You're doing great. We're only six feet up. Just jump out the door, Walter.

This is wide view of what's going on. We see the back of hovering helicopter. To its left is the international shipping vessel the Dolores which has placed a life raft between it and the helicopter. There is still some space the right of the frame where there's open water. That's t side of the helicopter Walter mistakenly jumped from. Aft he surfaces, he starts to drift away from the freighter.
Walter's treading water a fair distance from the freighte The crew (Chilean) has gathered at the bow of the freight The captain calls out to Walter through a megaphone.
We're sending a pontoon. Try to remain calm.
At this point a fin passes behind Walter.
(through the megaphone) Okay, if that's a porpoise--
(sort of to himself,
If what's a-- (noticing the fin) what?
If that is a porpoise, befriend it. Porpoises are mammals with rare intelligence and sympathy. They often protect swimmers from predators.
The fin circles by again.
If that's a shark, strike it. Their snouts are sensory hubs.
How do you-- I just see a fin. Can you get a bead on some more information?
On board the crew has a brief consultation.
(then, to Walter through
We're confident that's a shark.
The fin comes nearer. Walter steels himself. Then he find some presence of mind and power and is able to deter the thing away by thrashing at it with a few decent punches.
(after a moment) Okay, now we think that was a porpoise.
After another moments, another fin shows up.
That probably is a shark.
At this point, though, the pontoon arrives and Walter scrambles into it (he still has his briefcase).
Walter has dried off. He's being tended to by some young Chilean sailors. He's been sounding them out about where O'Connell is.
Sean O'Connell? He was picked up.
From your ship?
A pilot boat came. They took him. Four hours ago.
Took him where?
I don't know.
It's dawned on Walter that he's missed Sean. Just by a little.
Can we radio them? There's something I need to discuss with--
You jumped into the ocean with our radio components. No. We are, as you say, "on our own."
The freighter's hauling automobiles. The surface of the s looks like a mall parking lot. One of the Chilean sailors accompanies Walter on a walk among the car rows.
You can sleep where Sean did.
They stop alongside a Subaru. The Sailor opens the driver door. He means this is where Sean slept. In this Subaru. Walter's confused.
Sean slept here?
Yes.
In this Subaru Outback?
Yes. That's where our undocumented laborers sleep. Our Stevedores. He was photographing our workers.
He was photographing Chilean Stevedores?
Yeah.
(about the Outback) This was his room/car?
Now it will be your room/car.
Walter has gotten in. There are five Chilean Stevedores i the back in different states of rest - sleeping, reading, playing chess.
Hey. Walter.
They wave.
Did you guys, were you living in this car back seat when Sean O'Connell lived in the front seat?
Walter starts miming taking photographs.
Sean?
La Quintasencia....
The guy's pointing to where Walter is in the front seat.
La Quintasencia.
Is that-- Are you saying quin--
La Quintasencia...
Are you saying Quintessence? In the Spanish form? Yeah. Sean says that.
A deck Squall Alarm sounds. These guys leave the car quic (to perhaps batten something down). Walter notices the breaktime snack they were enjoying - half's been left beh
Is that Clementine cake? My mom makes-- I didn't know anyone else made that.
Walter's alone in the Subaru.
Clementine cake. Wow.

He reaches for some cake, it's been sliced into pieces, wrapped bakery style in some stray paper from the backsea Walter takes one such slice. While the storm lifts and lo the ship, Walter enjoys some clementine cake, then he not something about the paper scrap it's wrapped in. There's handwriting on it. Walter examines it.
What Walter's holding is a half-torn page bearing cursive handwriting. There is a date beside the word: EyjafjallajГ¶kull. Then TTL shoemount flash. Zoom bounce flash. Nikon Camera....
This is Sean's.
There is a later destination and date on the paper - and scrawl beside it.
...this is an itinerary.

During this storm, Walter has climbed up the crow's nest ladder and stands in the crow's nest with the English- Speaking Chilean Sailor who escorted him to the Subaru. Walter's showing him the paper - EyjafjallajГ¶kull
That's where Sean is. Tomorrow. This gibberish. I have to crack it.
Crack?
I have to crack the gibberish.
You don't have to crack anything. It's a volcano. In Iceland. That's the name. EyjafjallajГ¶kull.
...Sean's in Iceland. We're going past there, right? Can we land there?
We can get you there.
Can you get me there tomorrow?
We can get you there tomorrow, yes.
Would you like some Clementine cake?
Walter's brought the cake up with him.
It's very good. It tastes, man, exactly like my mom's. I didn't know Chilean mom's made this. Small world.
No thank you. I have to actually perform a function up here, during the storm. That's why I'm up here.
Oh. Sorry.
I have to monitor the mooring winches and wind Lasses.
And you're standing, I'm sorry, like right where I'm supposed to be looking.
Okay, I'm going to go, take my cake and.....
Walter starts to descend the crow's nest ladder.

The storm has broken. The sea is calm. The sun is out. Th is a huge ship. Walter's sitting on the bow, all by himse His briefcase is beside him. It's quiet. He's looking out the water, then (oddly) his cell phone rings.
...Hello?
Walter.
Yeah.
Todd Mahar. From eHarmony.

...Oh. Hey. (like it's weird to be getting a call out here from Todd Mahar) Um, do I owe you guys money? Because your supervisor was clear I can't get my 400 dollars back. But I don't think I'm going to renew-
No, I just wanted to see how you were doing. You didn't sound great last time.
The last time we talked? The time you told me I have no personality?
Well, you know, you just left your application so empty. Share something about yourself. It doesn't have to be major league.
Life's full of small accomplishments. What do you strive to do everyday, that you take pride in? Can I ask you that?
Well, I take my work seriously. Also keeping a tidy apartment. I help my sister out paying her bills now and then. But can we not list that? None of that stuff really seems like an accomplishment.
You know there's a way to consider it where the tasks you accomplish (paying some of your sister's rent--
Braces.
What's that?
She hasn't asked me for rent money. For like a year. But I did pay for her braces. She's 36.
Well, taking care of yourself and your household, your mom, after you do that without ever failing, for a long time, hey that becomes an accomplishment.
Some time passes. A bird flies by.
I fought a dolphin.
Today?
Yeah.
Aren't they supposed to be nice?
They are. I think they're probably the best mammal.
(meaning like aren't we
We're mammals.
Walter doesn't say anything about us being the best. Life heavy for him right now.
This mammal tried to protect me. And most of the other mammals I know, like the mammals at the office, they're dicks.
Why are you near dolphins?
I'm on a ship.
Where?
Near Greenland. I tracked a thumb here. To Nuuk, Greenland. I located the thumb. Now I'm fortunately going to Iceland to correct an oversight.
Well, I'm going to tweak your profile, add "sailing" or whatever to your Done Thats. I'll put Swims with Dolphins, too.
It was just one.
I can really put Swims with Dolphin. That sounds like you have a pet dolphin you swim with everyday. Can I handle this please? It's my job.
Okay, Todd.
You sound a little better?
Do I? Because I think I'm a little worse.
Walter's been equipped with a kayak pole and life vest. S of the crew assist him down a ladder to the ocean; others keep watch over a kayak waiting there.
It's a mile and half to Iceland. It's as far in as we can get with our hull size.
So. Okay. I'm supposed to kayak in?
Reykjavik is due north. You'll be there by 9 am.

Walter's quietly kayaking through an empty expanse of the Atlantic. His paddle makes noise; that's it. Then Cheryl Mellhoff emerges from underwater - but she's giant. She t up the whole horizon. She's catching her breath like she' been underwater for a while. Then her son Rich (giant) po up from underwater beside her. He catches his breath, too but he's pleased.
I stayed under longer.
Just barely.
Let's do it again.
Okay. One, two, three.
Cheryl fakes going underwater on three. Rich has. She's s above water. She's cheating. She stays there for a while, smiling. Then Rich pops up.
You're cheating.
Okay, okay. One two three.

They both get caught faking it this time, and they start laugh. Then they both go underwater. They're under for a time. A pretty long time, in fact. Then Cheryl surfaces. Rich doesn't. She's breathing again, but she expected to Rich and doesn't, and now she's concerned.
Rich...?
He's nowhere.
Rich?
Finally, he pops up. But he's coughing, was under too lon and has taken in some water; he's scared.
It's okay. Come here. Hey come here.
She hugs him.
Hey, it's okay.
He's freaked, he's crying a little.
Hey, don't worry. You're good. Don't worry. Hey...
After a moment, she begins to sing to distract him. She's singing Bob Marley's Three Little Birds pretty well.
Don't worry, about a thing, `cause every little thing, is gonna be all right. Don't worry. About a thing...

Walter looks on from (from his kayak). He's worried about lot of things, but what he's picturing soothes him too. T day dream fades. Walter keeps kayaking. It looks desolate then a guy in a rubber triathlon swimsuit swims by. Then another one does.
....shit.
A wide shot shows that Walter has kayaked near to the coa of Reykjavik, Iceland during the swimming portion of a triathlon. Now he's in the midst of a hundred pissed guys rubber swim suits.
Fuck. Sorry.
Walter's in the heart of Reykjavik, Iceland, driven throu the city. He's taking in the sights, looking around throu the cab window, when his phone rings again. He checks his caller I.D
Hey, Mom.
Hi, Walter.
What's up?
Oh, I'm just making some yogurt. With some banana.
Okay. Cool.
It snowed today. Didn't expect that. Not much. Just a light little cover. Very pretty. Less than an inch even.
That's awesome.
My piano got towed, Walter.
A moment goes by.
...Your piano got towed?
Yes. Odessa said it wasn't there. Where you said it was going to be.
She said possibly that it got towed. That that's not her space anymore.
I lent her money for that space.
Where are you, honey?
In Iceland.
That's nice.
Walter's out front of the capital building in Reykjavik texting Odessa.
Walter writes - Wtf on mom's p.?
He waits. This comes back - I had to go last minute to yo workshop out of town. Can you handle?
Walter sends - Can you please take care of this - I am in Iceland. I repeat. Iceland.
He gets back - thanks lots :) I'll have my phone off forseeably. Love, O.

Walter just sits there for a while - tending to the piano has been left to him - at this critical moment. He turns around. You can see the volcano (where Sean O'Connell is) looming way in the distance.
Walter has left. He's taken off. He's looking out the sma window, down at Iceland as he goes, down at EyjafjallajГ¶ the volcano he nearly reached. It's getting smaller. Walt watches as it does.
Home now, Walter lands at JFK. He's in economy, taking ou his laptop.
It is now safe to turn on portable electronic devices.
Walter's laptop is on. So he goes on eHarmony. Again, he tries to leave a wink for Cheryl. The reply he gets, agai is "unable to perform request."

It's two a.m. Walter is alone on a terminal moving walkwa He hasn't changed since we met him - he's still got hold his briefcase. He's looking (again) at the out of focus picture. He can't draw anything out of it.

location: PORT AUTHORITY CAR IMPOUND LOT, NEWARK, NJ

text: Walter hurries through a car impound facility. Among the of impounded cars, there is his mom's grand piano.

location: OFFICE, PORT AUTHORITY CAR IMPOUND LOT

text: It's Walter's turn in line.
Retrieving..?
My mom's piano.
...Make and color?
(doesn't really understand the question in regard to
It's a Baldwin? Um, Walnut, I guess? A Walnut Baldwin. Piano.
A moment goes by.
It's a piano.
I heard you.
It's right out there. I just walked by it. Do you have more than one piano?
Impound fees. I'm making your fees. Heavy duty tow fee. $370. Two nights overnight. $80.
Failure to display city vehicle inspection sticker. $112.
It's a piano.
The guy just keeps adding.
It's not a car. Its a musical instrument. I should have had my musical instrument inspected? By a government.
The guy ignores Walter. He just stays at his task which i adding money Walter doesn't have.

location: PORT AUTHORITY CAR IMPOUND LOT, NEWARK, NJ

text: Walter looks on while movers consider how to load his mom piano into the back of their moving van.
Where are we taking it?
We can't move into my mom's until tomorrow.
Well, what do you want me to do? Drive really slowly? We can store it at our warehouse and move it in the morning. But that's two moves. Separate billings.
Man.... You know what? (meaning they can leave without the piano) Don't worry about it.
What are you talking about?
Don't worry about it.
Walter walks over, lowers himself beneath the keyboard, f a grip, then rises and lifts the piano up by himself.
Walter's carrying the piano on his back, walking down the middle of the New Jersey Turnpike, slowing down traffic.
Walter climbs a set of stairs to the subway with the pian his back.
Walter sits on a bench waiting for the train. The Grand P is beside him.

Walter has brought the piano onto the subway. Then the su hits one of those mid-tunnel stops where the train stops, the lights go on and off. When the lights return we see t piano's gone. Walter's still there though.
Piano move (third) - $1,100.00

This is an empty (small) apartment. Walter and his sister ODESSA sit on the carpet. She's pretty, good spirit, a li flighty (also she's wearing braces). She's watching Walte write this piano moving check. But she's looking at a checkbook entry a few entries above it.
Does that say eHarmony? Four hundred dollars.
Yes.
(a little amused) Are you on eHarmony?
No.
Then why did you give them four hundred dollars?
I tried to join, but-- I don't really even want to be on it. I'm just trying to do this thing with someone at work.
(meaning do what) What?
At this point we see a piano float up into view outside t living room window beyond them, odd because they're fifte stories up.
I'm trying to do that PiГ±a Colada thing? (singing pretty well) "If you like PiГ±a Coladas, and getting caught in the rain while wearing a cape--"
That's not how it goes.

Well, the guy answers a personal ad and finds out it's his wife. They have a good laugh, then they make love on the cape while drinking PiГ±a Coladas or something, and wearing capes, I think. Anyway. I'm hoping she'll click my profile and not realize that she works in my office area. Then we can realize it and have a good laugh. Then--
Make love on a cape? While wearing capes? Because that's not what they do in the song.
No, then we can know that we picked each other out, you know, from the whole planet. Not just the cafeteria.
Walter's quiet for a moment.
... We're friends. I'd like there to be more.
I was hoping this web site (that they won't let me be on) would show her more.
Walter is putting his checkbook back in his briefcase. Od has noticed the out-of-focus photo Walter carries in it.
(about the picture) What's that?
I don't know. What do you think it is?
Odessa looks the photo for a while.
(trying to make it out) ...Triple A batteries working, as a team, to carry a fish tank up some apartment stairs.
Out the window we see that the piano is attached to a cra Movers have lifted it up to the fifteenth floor. Walter l out at it from the small, small room they're in.
We better tell them they need to shift that over to outside the big room.
What big room?
(sensing there is going to be some problem) The big room where the big piano is going to go.
This is the big room.
Walter's surprised. There's no way the piano fits in this space.
Hey, Odessa?
Yeah.
You know when I asked you to pick the apartment out for Mom, you understood that she was taking her piano along.
I did not understand that.
Oh, I thought I made that clear when I said the English sentence to you Mom's bringing her piano with her. A month ago.
I think when we were having that conversation I was using my blender, for a juice drink. It's quite a noisemaker.
Walter's trying to keep his composure (as a grand piano dangles out the window nearby).

Did you enjoy that juice drink? That you were making (for some reason) simultaneous to me talking to you about important matters? So, okay, right now the piano is hanging in the air, above a city, we can't fit it in here, and I'm not sure I can afford to move it anywhere else. So I hope you enjoyed that juice drink.
A retirement facility administrator has joined them to de with the piano problem. They're all convened at the kitch counter.  The piano's in view out the window, dangling th
The instrument will fit in one of our Villa apartments. Those units, though, are more spacious, and more highly priced.
Quietly, Walter's getting really worried about money.
Or you can remain with the unit lease you have, the less expensive one, and possibly sell the piano?

We can't. It's the only thing she really wanted to take along. I think it's really best for her. She can still play. Reading's not that easy for her now. She doesn't really have any friends in New York.
Well, a Villa Apartment comes open in three weeks.
What's that move-in like. In terms of deposits and-- for Villa living? In a Villa situation?
On your move-in we'll need first month's, last month's and your full deposit. $6,300.
This is a little more than Walter has around. He's starti to show it.
How much should I make this deposit for today? To reserve it.
Nine hundred.
Walter's writing the word Villa in the memo space of his check.
Then he checks his balance -   he has $7,100 in there.

head_text.subj: THIS IS A SERIOUS REALIZATION FOR WALTER. THIS EXPENSE WI

text: Walter and Odessa ride the elevator down. Walter's pretty stressed.
Where's that frigging Clementine cake wrapper thing...

Walter takes out the torn piece of paper Sean O'Connell h written some of his itinerary on (also that was wrapped around cake). Walter's now concentrating on the destinati under Iceland. The one where the destination name has bee torn off. It just has the dates and words:
And one that looks like Warlock.
Then letters from a strange looking alphabet.
(trying to figure it out) Warlock...
(meaning the paper) What is that?

I almost found someone I was looking for. For work. In Iceland. This is where he's going next. I just don't know where it is. (looking at the paper) Warlock. Little weird deer. Like kind of a fez-style hat.
What are you talking about?
That's what these things are. Klipspringer. Koofiyad. I just don't know what they add up to. I put them all in Google nothing comes up.
Walter and Odessa are back in Battery Park. The piano is still across the street dangling from a winch 15 stories Walter has just written (yet) another check to the mover.
...Is everything okay? At work? Are you sure?
(trying to seem confident) Yeah. Don't worry.
Hey. Happy birthday, Walter.

Odessa has handed him two wrapped gifts. Walter begins to unwrap them. Inside are two toys: A Stretch Armstrong and from yesteryear, the cheap drawing tablet where little me filings are moved about with a magnetic wand to add featu to a cartoon face.
Those were your favorite toys when you were a kid. You don't remember?
Yeah, I do.... Thanks.
Odessa gives Walter a kiss.
Walter's riding the subway to work. Everything looks pret normal except there's a small African Antelope walking around.

Walter gets in the elevator - but already in there are Te Hendricks and the executive board member guys. Walter has been caught off guard. He's holding toys - the Stretch Armstrong and drawing tablet.
Oh. Hey.
Walter offers his hand to Ted.
You know we haven't really had a chance to talk yet. I know you're deciding who's vital to the transition. And I wanted to let you know what I do--
You're vital here?
I am. Totally.
Why are you holding toys?
...It's my birthday.
...you wanted toys.
No... Um, my sister gave me these.
(nodding at Walter's
What does that do?
My... (doesn't want to call it a
...item?
Yeah, you're toy.
His arms and legs stretch outward. Um. But that's not-- I wanted, before we have the chance to talk, I need to discuss an asset situation with you.
Walter begins to open his briefcase to stash the toys, bu he's nervous so it drops.
Walter's in Ted's glass partitioned work space.
(after being told it's lost, pissed) A photographic negative? I thought those had all been processed?
I've processed the digitization of every single photograph in Life's library. Two million and eleven. But we haven't been able to locate this last negative.
I know. Because I've been asking for it. Because it's the Quintessence fucking one that I told my boss we had. It's the cover. You seriously lost a photographer's work? At Life?
WALTER' MOM APPEARS ONCE MORE IN THE HALLWAY; she's out there, peeking into this office.
I'm confident we'll find it.
Why are you confident we'll find it?
Walter has no reason to be confident he'll find it. So he doesn't say anything.
That doesn't give me confidence, a no-answer. You're in assets, I guess?
Yes.
This doesn't reflect very well on you.
Walter's at a loss.
During an evaluation week.
I've been here nine years--
(gesturing out his cell
Here. Call Helmut Newton. Tell him you lost his picture.
